head.title: Layered Double Hydroxide-Derived Intermetallic Ni3GaC0.25 Catalysts for Dry Reforming of Methane | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: Layered Double Hydroxide-Derived Intermetallic Ni3GaC0.25 Catalysts for Dry Reforming of Methane

A NiMgGa-layered double hydroxide (NMG-LDH) is synthesized as an efficient catalyst precursor for dry reforming of methane (DRM). NMG-LDH is converted to an intermetallic Ni3Ga/MgO catalyst upon reduction. Compared to a monometallic Ni/MgO catalyst prepared from NiMg-LDH, the Ni3Ga/MgO catalyst exhibits high CH4 (∼48%) and CO2 (∼52%) conversions as well as excellent stability against coking during DRM. The reversible phase transition between intermetallic Ni3Ga and Ni3GaCx is demonstrated by in situ characterizations with the interstitial carbon being involved in the catalytic cycle of DRM to produce CO and H2. According to density functional theory calculations and the experimental study, the LDH-derived Ni3Ga intermetallic catalyst is converted to the Ni3GaC0.25 phase when carbon atoms dissociated from CH4 penetrate into the octahedral interstices of the Ni3Ga lattice during DRM at 600 °C. The formed Ni3GaC0.25 is proven effective in converting the interstitial carbon rapidly into CO to suppress its conversion to the coke, thus improving the stability of the catalyst.

div.p:
A NiMgGa-layered double hydroxide (NMG-LDH) is synthesized as an efficient catalyst precursor for dry reforming of methane (DRM). NMG-LDH is converted to an intermetallic Ni
3
Ga/MgO catalyst upon reduction. Compared to a monometallic Ni/MgO catalyst prepared from NiMg-LDH, the Ni
3
Ga/MgO catalyst exhibits high CH
4
(∼48%) and CO
2
(∼52%) conversions as well as excellent stability against coking during DRM. The reversible phase transition between intermetallic Ni
3
Ga and Ni
3
GaC
x
is demonstrated by
in situ
characterizations with the interstitial carbon being involved in the catalytic cycle of DRM to produce CO and H
2
. According to density functional theory calculations and the experimental study, the LDH-derived Ni
3
Ga intermetallic catalyst is converted to the Ni
3
GaC
0.25
phase when carbon atoms dissociated from CH
4
penetrate into the octahedral interstices of the Ni
3
Ga lattice during DRM at 600 °C. The formed Ni
3
GaC
0.25
is proven effective in converting the interstitial carbon rapidly into CO to suppress its conversion to the coke, thus improving the stability of the catalyst.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The post industrialization era has witnessed an explosive increase in CO
2
emission caused by the enormous usage of fossil fuels, which has accelerated global warming and poses a serious threat of climate change.
(1,2)
Over the past 30 years, global efforts have led to the formulation of multiple policies to mitigate the climate change. Among them, carbon capture and storage (CCS) is the most prominent and direct technological solution.
(3)
However, the high costs incurred in the CO
2
capture process, liquefaction, transportation, and landfilling and the associated safety issues such as re-leakage of the gas have been revealed as the limitations of CCS. The carbon capture and utilization (CCU) technology goes beyond CCS by converting the captured CO
2
into high value-added products, such as syngas (CO + H
2
), chemical intermediates, and synthetic fuels, and hence, it is an effective way of recycling CO
2
.
(4)

Among various CCU technologies developed, catalytic CO
2
hydrogenation has been most widely investigated because it allows the use of well-developed catalysts, reactors, and processes in the chemical industry.
(5−7)
However, it requires a large amount of H
2
, which should be produced by using a renewable energy, and the process is still under development. In this context, dry reforming of methane (DRM) is a CCU technology that has recently been garnered significant attention for the generation of CO and H
2
from the reaction between two greenhouse gases of CH
4
and CO
2
.
(8)
Thermodynamically, DRM is an endothermic reaction (
eq 1
) that requires operating temperatures above 800 °C,
(9)
resulting in high energy consumption.
(10)
In addition, such a high operating temperature and a high C/H ratio in the feed cause severe coking and sintering of the active metal, thereby rapidly deactivate the catalyst.
(11)
(1)
(2)
(3)
(4)

A strategy proposed to address this limitation is the development of effective DRM catalysts that operate effectively at low temperatures below 700 °C.
(8,10)
Noble metal-based catalysts offer excellent activity and stability in DRM reactions at low temperatures, yet their high cost is not conducive to commercialization.
(12−14)
Therefore, relatively inexpensive modified Ni catalysts have been developed as cost-effective alternatives for DRM catalysis.
(15−17)
However, coking from the polymeric carbon deposition by side reactions is a critical drawback of Ni-based catalysts (
eqs 3
and
4
). Carbon deposition occurs mainly because C–C bonds are formed by the polymerization of surface carbon (C*) species formed from CH
4
dissociation. To prevent carbon deposition during the reaction, effective removal of C* species through interference with their reaction on the catalyst surface is essential. Several strategies have been developed for this purpose including the following: (i) application of efficient support materials to maximize the metal–support interaction,
(18−20)
(ii) use of promoters (alkali and alkaline earth metals or transition metals) to increase basicity and reducibility,
(21−23)
and (iii) introduction of a secondary metal to improve the redox property of the main metal by forming a bimetallic alloy for example.
(24−28)
Encapsulation of active species in a core–shell structure
(17,29)
or using a mesoporous material
(13,30−32)
can also protect the active metal species from agglomeration during high-temperature reactions.

Recently, Ni-based intermetallic compounds and their carbides have been reported to improve the catalytic performance and thermal stability.
(33−36)
The adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates can be tailored by changing the electronic structure of the Ni center using a ligand effect or by changing the interatomic distance of surface Ni through an ensemble effect.
(37)
For example, penetration of carbon atoms into the interstitial sites of the Ni–Zn structure afforded Ni–Zn intermetallic carbides with altered electronic properties that exhibited high catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of alkynes.
(38)
Similarly, Ni–Ga intermetallic compounds exhibited a high activity for CO
2
reduction to methanol and a high stability in light alkane dehydrogenation.
(39,40)
In the CO
2
reduction, the Ni–Ga compound was shown to bind the oxygen intermediate with an optimal strength.
(39)
The optimal binding of the oxygen intermediate enables the facile removal of C* from the catalyst surface, which results in high activity as well as stability.
(31)
In addition, the large ensemble of catalytic Ni sites can be modulated by the formation of the Ni–Ga intermetallic structure, which confers high coke resistance.
(40)
Herein, we hypothesize that this could be a promising approach for the preparation of efficient catalysts with high activity and stability for low-temperature DRM, with the ability to suppress coke formation while allowing facile activation of both CH
4
and CO
2
.

The synthesis of Ni–Ga intermetallic compounds is challenging because it requires high-temperature annealing, which induces agglomeration of the intermetallic nanoparticles (NPs) to reduce the active surface area.
(41)
We solved the problem by using layered double hydroxide (LDH) as a precursor. LDH comprises positively charged host layers with a brucite structure and anion interlayers. Because the host layer is formed with two or more metal cations with atom-scale interspersion in a well-ordered crystal, the LDH structure serves as an efficient precursor for the preparation of intermetallic compounds.
(42)
The composition and particle size distribution of intermetallic compounds can be controlled simply through sequential topotactic transformations at various temperatures and gas atmospheres.
(43)
For example, uniform and highly dispersed Ni–In intermetallic catalysts were successfully synthesized using an LDH precursor with facile control of the particle size and composition.
(44)
The prepared Ni–In intermetallic catalyst showed superior catalytic performance in unsaturated aldehyde hydrogenation compared to a monometallic Ni catalyst due to the uniformly dispersed Ni–In intermetallic NPs and the enhanced electronic properties of Ni modulated by In.
(44)
Similarly, the Ni–Ga intermetallic structures derived from the LDH precursor are expected to offer unique structural and electronic properties that could impart high catalytic activity and stability for DRM. There have been a limited number of previous studies on Ni-based catalysts derived from LDHs for DRM.
(45−50)

Thus, in this work, we successfully synthesized Ni
3
Ga intermetallic catalysts through reduction of a NiMgGa (NMG)-LDH precursor prepared by separate nucleation and aging steps. Highly dispersed Ni
3
Ga NPs on the MgO (Ni
3
Ga/MgO) catalysts showed significantly higher CH
4
and CO
2
conversions in DRM, compared to monometallic catalysts. Various characterization methods were employed to investigate the active phase responsible for the improved DRM performance and reaction mechanisms. In particular,
in situ
XRD analysis was performed by varying the CO
2
/CH
4
feed ratio to investigate the dynamic structural evolution of the active phase generated under real DRM conditions. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were also performed to determine a plausible structure of the Ni
3
GaC
x
intermetallic carbide and free-energy profile of DRM on model surface structures. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on Ni
3
Ga intermetallic catalysts prepared using a LDH structure and applied for DRM.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
NMG-LDH was synthesized via on separate nucleation and aging steps, with slight modifications to a previously reported method.
(51)
First, 0.654 g of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate [Ni(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O, ≥99%, Sigma-Aldrich], 1.73 g of magnesium(II) nitrate hexahydrate [Mg(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O, ≥ 99%, Sigma-Aldrich], and 0.931 g of gallium(III) nitrate hydrate [Ga(NO
3
)
3
·
x
H
2
O, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich] were dissolved in 75 mL of distilled water by stirring to form a homogeneous solution. A separate solution containing 0.47 g of sodium carbonate (Na
2
CO
3
, ≥99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich) and 0.81 g of sodium hydroxide (NaOH, ≥97%, Sigma-Aldrich) in 75 mL of distilled water was then quickly added to the solution of the Ni, Mg, and Ga precursors. Upon mixing and stirring, the color of the solution immediately turned green. After stirring for 1 min, the resulting solution was sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 120 °C for 24 h. Then, the autoclave reactor was allowed to cool down to room temperature (25 °C) and the inside solution was washed with 1.5 L of water, and the green precipitate was collected by filtration. The collected precipitate was dried in a vacuum oven overnight at 80 °C. Reference catalysts containing two nitrate precursors were prepared in the same way by changing only the amount of the metal salt to maintain a similar weight ratio of the NMG-LDH catalysts; these were named Ni/MgO-pre and Ga/MgO-pre. Samples of the as-synthesized NMG-LDH and reference catalysts were reduced at different temperatures in 50% H
2
/Ar for 5 h. Depending on the reduction temperature, the samples are named NMG-
X
(
X
= 400, 500, 600, 700, and 800) and the reference samples reduced at 600 °C are referred to as Ni/MgO and Ga/MgO. Another reference (NiGa/MgO) catalyst was prepared by the conventional incipient wetness impregnation method. The solution containing Ni(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O and Ga(NO
3
)
3
·
x
H
2
O in the same composition as LDH was mixed with MgO (Sigma-Aldrich). The resulting precursor was dried in air at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined in air at 450 °C for 3 h.

DRM was carried out in a quartz fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 0.25 in. The catalyst (50 mg) was loaded and pretreated in a 50% H
2
/Ar balance (50 sccm flow) at 600 °C for 5 h. After reduction, the reactor was purged with Ar for 30 min to remove the remaining H
2
. A reactant gas with a CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
ratio of 1:1:1 was then fed into the reactor at atmospheric pressure. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 18–54 L·h
–1
·g
cat
–1
. The gaseous products including H
2
, N
2
, CO, CH
4
, and CO
2
released from the reactor were analyzed by online gas chromatography (GC, Agilent Technologies 7890A) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD, Carboxen 1000 column). Catalytic performance was evaluated at a steady state after at least 3 h in the gas stream for conversions of CO
2
(
X
CO
2
) and CH
4
(
X
CH
4
) and selectivity to H
2
(
S
H
2
). The carbon balance of each experiment was good at 97 ± 3 wt %.
(5)
(6)
(7)

X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the synthesized and spent catalysts were obtained using a Rigaku Ultima III with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154178 nm). To investigate the reduction behavior of the catalyst,
in situ
powder XRD was also performed using a SmartLab diffractometer (Rigaku) with a D/teX Ultra 250 detector under various gas flow rates. Before the measurement, the as-synthesized catalyst (45 ± 5 mg) was placed in a black quartz cuvette and reduced at 600 °C at a heating rate of 25 K·min
–1
in a flow of 50% H
2
in Ar (20 sccm) for 5 h. After the H
2
pretreatment, the reaction gas (CH
4
/CO
2
= 1/1, total flow: 30 sccm) was introduced, and the XRD patterns were recorded under catalytically relevant conditions of DRM at 600 °C for 5 h. To change the CO
2
/CH
4
ratio (1, 2, and 3) in the feed, the flow of CO
2
was fixed at 10 sccm, while varying CH
4
flow. Both normal and
in situ
powder XRD patterns were measured at a power of 45 kV and 200 mA with a scan range of 10–80° and a scan rate of 4°·min
–1
.

High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was performed at 200 kV with high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM, JEM-2100F, Jeol) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained using an FESEM-S4800 of Hitachi. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained at −196 °C with 50 mg of the sample on a BELSORP-max II analyzer (Bel Co.). Before the measurement, the sample was pretreated at 50 °C overnight under vacuum. The specific BET surface area was calculated using adsorption data in the relative pressure (
P
/
P
0
) range of 0.05–0.25. Temperature programmed reduction (H
2
-TPR) by H
2
was performed using a BELCAT II analyzer (Bel Co.). First, 50 mg of the catalyst was purged with He (50 sccm) at 25 °C for 30 min and then heated to 150 °C and maintained at this temperature for 2 h. After cooling to 25 °C, 10% H
2
in He (50 sccm) was introduced and allowed to stabilize for 1 h. The consumption of H
2
was monitored with a TCD between 35 and 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 K·min
–1
. Temperature-programmed desorption of CO
2
(CO
2
-TPD) was performed using an AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics). The sample was purged and heated to 150 °C with the same method as for H
2
-TPR. After cooling to 35 °C, 10% CO
2
in He (30 sccm) was introduced and held for 1 h. After CO
2
adsorption, the temperature was increased to 600 °C at a rate of 10 K·min
–1
, and the desorption of CO
2
from the catalyst surface was monitored using a TCD. The content of metal (Ni, Mg, and Ga) in the catalyst was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Varian 700-ES).

X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was performed on a 6D beamline of the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, South Korea (3.0 GeV, 400 mA). The synchrotron radiation was monochromated using a Si (111) double-crystal monochromator to remove high-order harmonics. The spectrum of the Ni K-edge (
E
0
= 8333 eV) was recorded in the transmission mode. The incident beam was detuned by 10% to minimize harmonic interference. Background removal and normalization of the Ni K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were performed using the ATHENA module of the IFEFFIT software program. As a reference sample, Ni
3
Ga powder was prepared according to a reported procedure.
(34)
NiO (99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich) and metallic Ni foils were also used as references. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo-Fisher ESCALAB 250XI) was performed using an Al Kα source. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of spent catalysts was performed on a TGA5500 (TA Instruments) in a temperature range of 35–900 °C in air flow (10 K·min
–1
).

The bulk structure optimization of Ni, Ni
3
Ga
1
, and Ni
3
Ga
1
C
x
and the mechanistic investigation of DRM on these materials were performed based on DFT calculations using the Vienna ab initio simulation package.
(52,53)
The electronic structure was described using the vdW-DF2 exchange–correlation functional implemented within a generalized gradient approximation was used.
(54)
The kinetic cutoff and convergence criteria for an atom were set to 450 eV and 0.01 eV/A, respectively. The space groups of Ni and Ni
3
Ga
1
were
Fm
3̅
m
and
Pm
3̅
m
, respectively. The structure of Ni
3
Ga
1
C
x
was modelled by inserting a C atom into the interstitial sites of a Ni
3
Ga
1
lattice according to the literature.
(55)
The surface slabs of all the three materials consist of a (111) surface structure. The slab contained 4 × 4 × 4 metal atoms in the
x
-,
y
-, and
z
-directions, where the bottom two layers were constrained, whereas the upper two layers were relaxed. The interaction between the slabs was prevented by using a 10 Å vacuum. The
k
-point sampling of the bulk and surface slabs was taken using gamma-centered mesh grids of 16 × 16 × 16 and 4 × 4 × 1, respectively.

The free-energy change of the surface reaction, Δ
G
, was calculated according to the equation Δ
G
= Δ
E
+ ΔZPE + Δ∫
C
p
d
T
–
T
Δ
S
, where
E
, ZPE,
C
p
,
T
, and
S
refer to the electronic energy, zero-point energy, heat capacity, temperature, and entropy of an adsorbed species, respectively. The harmonic limit approximation and the Shomate equation were adopted for the free-energy calculation of surface species and gas-phase molecules, respectively. The transition-state structures and their energies were obtained using the Bayesian transition-state search module implemented in CatLearn.
(56,57)

div.h3:
Characterization of NMG-LDH-Derived Ni
3
Ga Intermetallic Catalysts
div.div:
The structure of as-prepared NMG-LDH prepared using Ni, Mg, and Ga nitrate precursors was confirmed by XRD (Figure S1,
Supporting Information
). Hydrothermal reaction at 120 °C afforded a highly crystalline LDH structure with distinct characteristic XRD patterns. The overall morphology of NMG-LDH observed by SEM and TEM images resembled a hexagonal plate with an average diameter of 100 nm (
Figure S2
). Each element (Ni, Ga, and Mg) was uniformly distributed across the entire hexagonal plate as confirmed by HAADF-STEM images with the corresponding EDS elemental mapping (
Figure S3
). The LDH structure of NMG comprised a 2D plate with positively charged host layers (containing Ni
2+
, Mg
2+
, and Ga
3+
) of a brucite structure and hydroxide anion interlayers. Upon hydrogen treatment at 600 °C for 5 h, the NMG-LDH precursor formed the Ni
3
Ga intermetallic structure supported on MgO exhibiting a distinct XRD pattern (
Figure S4
) and a uniform particle size of ∼7 nm as determined by TEM analysis and XRD line broadening (
Figure S5a
). The two metal nitrate precursors (Ga/MgO-pre and Ni/MgO-pre) exhibiting hexagonal plate shapes were also transformed from their hydroxide phases to metallic Ga and Ni after the reduction at 600 °C (
Figure S5b,c
). The reduced Ni monometallic catalysts (Ni/MgO) had a uniform particle size of ∼9 nm, slightly larger than that of NMG-600 (
Figure S5b
). LDH has the general formula [M
1–
x
2+
M
x
3+
(OH)
2
]
z
+
A
z
/
n
n
–
·
m
H
2
O, where M
2+
and M
3+
are divalent and trivalent metal cations located in the host layer, respectively, and A
n
–
is the exchangeable anion in the interlayer region that compensates for the positive charge of the host layer.
(43)
In the Ni/MgO-pre sample, both Ni and Mg are divalent cations and the LDH structure cannot be formed because there are no trivalent metal cations. In contrast, the Ga/MgO-pre sample can form the LDH structure because of the presence of both divalent (Mg
2+
) and trivalent (Ga
3+
) cations. This explains why the crystal structures are different, even though the two samples were synthesized according to the same method. The relative molar ratios of each element in the NMG-LDH (Ni/Mg/Ga = 1:2.6:1.1), Ni/MgO-pre (Ni/Mg/Ga = 1:6.9:0), and Ga/MgO-pre (Ni/Mg/Ga = 0:4:1) catalysts were determined by ICP-OES. The chemical composition and textural properties of each catalyst are listed in
Table S1
.

The phase evolution of the MgO-supported Ni
3
Ga intermetallic structure from NMG-LDH was investigated
via in situ
XRD in a controlled reducing environment (
Figure
1
a). Between 25 and 300 °C, the NMG-LDH structure gradually transformed into a low-crystalline structure under 50% H
2
/Ar. Above 400 °C, reflections corresponding to MgO, NiO, and metallic Ni appeared in the XRD pattern. The abrupt change in the crystalline phases at 400 °C was consistent with a sharp reduction peak in H
2
-TPR (
Figure S6
). Interestingly, Ga did not show any crystalline phase below 400 °C; however, Ga
2
O
3
and Ga metal phases began to appear above 500 °C. The Ni
3
Ga intermetallic structure was formed above 600 °C, showing characteristic reflections at 43.6 and 50.8° corresponding to the (111) and (200) planes, respectively (
Figure
1
a). After reduction treatment, NMG-LDH was converted to mixed phases of Ni
3
Ga, Ga, and MgO.
Scheme 1
illustrates the structural evolution of the NMG-LDH precursor to Ni NPs by H
2
reduction above 400 °C and then to Ni
3
Ga intermetallic NPs by reduction above 600 °C. HR-TEM images confirmed that the synthesized NMG-600 was composed of Ni
3
Ga intermetallic NPs of an ∼7 nm size well dispersed over MgO (
Figures
1
b and
S5a
).

div.p:
Figure 1. (a)
In situ
XRD patterns of NMG-LDH reduced in 50% H
2
/Ar at 25–600 °C. Enlarged XRD patterns (range 41–45°) are provided for clarification. (b) HR-TEM and HAADF-STEM images with corresponding EDS elemental mapping of NMG-600.

div.div:
Scheme 1. Schematic of the Preparation of the Ni
3
Ga Intermetallic Catalyst from the NMG-LDH Precursor

The catalysts reduced in 50% H
2
/Ar at 600 °C for 5 h were further characterized by HR-TEM and HAADF-STEM images with EDS elemental mapping (
Figure
1
b). The overall morphology of the reduced catalysts consisted of crystalline Ni
3
Ga NPs embedded in MgO nanosheets. The exposed lattice distance of the crystallites was 0.208 nm corresponding to the (111) plane of Ni
3
Ga (
Figure
1
b, insets). HAADF-STEM and the corresponding elemental mapping of NMG-600 catalysts showed a uniform distribution of the Ni and Ga in Ni
3
Ga NPs on the MgO support (
Figure
1
b). These results confirm that the Ni
3
Ga intermetallic structure was successfully synthesized in the reduction step without forming separate single element particles. Detailed concerning the sizes of the metal NPs in the reduced catalysts are provided in
Figure S5
.

XPS analysis was also performed to characterize the electronic state of Ni in LDH and its reduced catalyst (
Figure S7
). The binding energy of Ni in Ni
3
Ga was observed at 852.1 eV, negatively shifted from that of metallic Ni
0
position (852.6 eV),
(58)
indicating that the Ni atoms in Ni
3
Ga had a higher electron density than that of the pristine Ni metal. This Ni with a higher electron density can bind CO
2
more strongly as confirmed by CO
2
-TPD (
Figure S8
). Thus, NMG-600 exhibits a much higher desorption temperature compared to monometallic Ni/MgO and Ga/MgO. Taken all the characterization results together, we can conclude that NMG-LDH serves as a suitable precursor for generating Ni
3
Ga intermetallic NPs homogeneously embedded in the MgO support.

Catalytic DRM was performed over LDH-derived catalysts under the reaction conditions of 600 °C, 1 bar, a WHSV of 54 L·h
–1
·g
cat
–1
, and a 1:1:1 ratio of CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
(
Figure
2
). Prior to the reaction, the catalysts were reduced in 50% H
2
/Ar flow at 600 °C for 5 h.
Figure
2
a,b shows CH
4
and CO
2
conversions of the LDH-derived catalysts, NMG-600, Ni/MgO, Ga/MgO, and a physically mixed Ni/MgO–Ga/MgO. The most conspicuous feature of the NMG-600 catalyst was that it maintained the initial high conversions (48% for CH
4
and 52% for CO
2
) for 12 h, whereas the Ni/MgO catalysts exhibited more than 30% of deactivation during the 12 h reaction. The Ga/MgO catalyst showed a negligible conversion of CH
4
and CO
2
. The physically mixed Ni/MgO–Ga/MgO catalyst showed activity and stability very similar to those of Ni/MgO, demonstrating that intermetallic Ni
3
Ga is both an active and stable catalytic phase for DRM. This effect cannot be realized by physically mixing Ni and Ga phases.

div.p:
Figure 2. Performance of LDH-derived catalysts in DRM. Conversions of CH
4
(a) and CO
2
(b) over NMG-600, Ni/MgO, Ga/MgO, and physically mixed Ni/MgO–Ga/MgO catalysts. Reaction conditions: CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1:1:1, 600 °C, 1 bar, WHSV: 54 L·h
–1
·g
cat
–1
. (c) Stability test of the NMG-600 catalyst in continuous DRM for 72 h.

div.div:
The NMG-LDH catalysts treated at different reduction temperatures (NMG-
X
;
X
= reduction temperature) were also tested for DRM (
Figure S9
). The NMG-400 catalyst produced only the metallic Ni phase (
Figures S6
and
1
a), which resulted in severe reactor clogging after 3 h of reaction on stream (
Figure S9
). The performance of Ni/MgO suggests that the monometallic Ni suffers from significant coking during the reaction by CH
4
decomposition (
eq 3
) and CO disproportionation (
eq 4
). The NMG-600 catalyst showed the highest performance, and the NMG-700 and NMG-800 catalysts showed decreased conversions due to sintering owing to their high reduction temperatures (
Figure S5e,f
), although they retained a similar stability.

The effects of reaction temperature were investigated using the optimized NMG-600 catalyst in the range of 500–800 °C (
Figure S10
). The NMG-600 catalyst worked even at relatively low reaction temperatures, showing 16 and 20% of CH
4
and CO
2
conversions at 500 °C, respectively. Notably, the CO
2
conversion was higher than the CH
4
conversion between 500 and 800 °C because the generated H
2
reacted with CO
2
to induce the reverse water-gas shift (
eq 2
). As the reaction temperature increased, the conversions of both CH
4
and CO
2
also increased. At 800 °C, the reaction reached near-equilibrium conversions under the present reaction conditions.

To investigate the specificity of the Ni
3
Ga intermetallic structure derived from LDH, the DRM performance of the NMG-600 catalyst was compared with that of a NiGa/MgO catalyst prepared by the conventional impregnation method. Although the impregnated NiGa/MgO catalyst showed high activities (45 and 47% in CH
4
and CO
2
conversions, respectively) without severe deactivation, the overall catalytic performance of NMG-600 was superior to that of the impregnated NiGa/MgO catalyst (
Figure S11a,b
). It was due to a significantly smaller size and more uniform distribution of Ni
3
Ga NPs in the NMG-600 catalyst (
Figure S11d–f
). This result justifies the use of the LDH precursor with an atomic-scale mixing of elements. The long-term stability test was also conducted on the NMG-600 catalyst with 54 L·h
–1
·g
cat
–1
at 600 °C for 3 days (
Figure
2
c). The CH
4
and CO
2
conversions of NMG-600 remained stable without noticeable deactivation. Specifically, the catalyst exhibited a low deactivation rate of 0.048%·h
–1
for CH
4
and 0.055%·h
–1
for CO
2
, which is superior to other reported results under similar reaction conditions (
Table S2
). Conversely, the Ni/MgO reference catalyst underwent significant deactivation in the early stage of the reaction (∼10 h) due to the coke deposition and agglomeration of Ni NPs (
Figure S12
). Overall, the LDH-derived intermetallic structure of NMG-600 exhibited different catalytic behavior compared to that of the monometallic catalyst (Ni/MgO) during DRM.

div.h3:
Identification of the Active Catalytic Phase: An Intermetallic Carbide, Ni
3
GaC
x
div.div:
Typically, Ni-based catalysts undergo severe coking at low reaction temperatures, which deactivate the catalysts as the carbonaceous species grow on the surface.
(8)
Therefore, the amount of carbon species formed on the surface of the catalyst during the DRM reaction is closely related to its catalytic activity and stability. The XRD pattern of the spent Ni/MgO catalyst in
Figure
3
a after DRM for 12 h clearly showed a high-intensity graphitic carbon reflection along with the metallic Ni reflections. On the other hand, the spent Ni–Ga intermetallic NMG-600 catalyst did not show any graphitic carbon or metallic Ni reflections. Instead, the broad XRD reflections at 43.4 and 50.4° were assigned to the carburized Ni
3
Ga intermetallic structure and the broad reflection at 36° was due to Ga. Thus, the significantly enhanced catalytic activity and stability of the NMG-600 catalyst distinct from Ni/MgO is due to intermetallic Ni
3
Ga, which was carburized
in situ
during the reaction.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) XRD patterns of the spent NMG-600 and Ni/MgO catalysts. (b)
In situ
XRD patterns of NMG-600 under the DRM conditions with CH
4
/CO
2
= 1:1 at 600 °C. Magnified XRD patterns in the 41–45° and 49–53° ranges showing the transformation of Ni
3
Ga to Ni
3
GaC
x
.

div.div:
Next, we investigated the evolution of the Ni
3
Ga intermetallic catalyst by
in situ
XRD under simulated reaction conditions for in-depth understanding of the active catalytic sites (
Figure
3
b). As mentioned, the as-prepared NMG-LDH was completely reduced to the Ni
3
Ga phase during the reduction step at 600 °C for 5 h. This caused the reducing gas flow (50% H
2
in at 20 sccm) was switched to the DRM reaction feed (CH
4
/CO
2
= 1:1, total flow: 30 sccm). Then, the XRD reflections for Ni
3
Ga to shift toward lower angles within 1 h, indicating that Ni
3
Ga (structure type L1
2
) was converted into the Ni
3
GaC
x
(structure type E2
1
) phase, as carbon atoms penetrated to the octahedral interstices of the Ni
3
Ga lattice.
(55)
This Ni
3
GaC
x
structure persisted for up to 5 h during the
in situ
XRD measurement, demonstrating that the carbon atoms initially generated by DRM at 600 °C on the NMG-600 catalyst formed the stable Ni
3
GaC
x
phase instead of polymeric carbon.

The formation of the Ni
3
GaC
x
phase during the DRM reaction was also confirmed by XAS. The Ni K-edge XANES spectrum of the spent NMG-600 catalyst clearly demonstrated the formation of the Ni
3
GaC
x
phase in the spent NMG-600 catalysts (
Figure S13
). The pre-edge peak observed for NMG-600 at 8333 eV is due to the quadrupolar 1s → 3d transition, and its intensity is lower than that of the Ni metal and higher than that of Ni oxide references. The partial charge transfer from the Ni metal to the non-metal atom (carbon) suggests the formation of the Ni
3
GaC
x
phase during the reaction.
(59)
EXAFS spectra in
Figure
4
a also showed the formation of the Ni
3
GaC
x
phase in the NMG-600 catalyst. There are two major differences between EXAFS spectra of NMG-600 and Ni/MgO obtained after the reaction. First, due to the formation of the Ni–Ga bond, the Ni–Ni(Ga) scattering peak (at 2.1 Å) of NMG-600 shifted slightly to a longer radial distance than those of the Ni/MgO catalyst and Ni foil reference.
(60)
Second, NMG-600 showed a strong scattering peak at 1.7 Å resulting from bonding with carbon, which was absent in the Ni/MgO and Ni
3
Ga reference samples.
(15,61)

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Ni K-edge
k
2
-weighted Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectra of the spent NMG-600 and Ni/MgO catalysts. Ni foil and Ni
3
Ga were used as standards. No phase-shift correction was applied to the Fourier transform. (b) TGA curves of the spent NMG-600 and Ni/MgO catalysts after reaction. (c) HR-TEM and HAADF-STEM images with the corresponding EDS elemental mapping of the spent NMG-600 catalyst.

div.div:
TGA under air flow was performed to measure the amount of carbon on the spent catalysts after 12 h of the reaction.
Figure
4
b indicates the presence of two significant weight losses at low temperatures (100–400 °C) related to the combustion of the amorphous carbon or carbide species
(62)
and weight loss above 400 °C due to graphitic carbon. The less reactive graphitic carbon is responsible for the deactivation of Ni-based catalysts. The weight loss of the Ni/MgO catalyst at the high temperature was ∼41.5 wt %, which is 24 times higher than that of the NMG-600 catalyst (1.7 wt %). The main weight loss of NMG-600 (14.9%) was observed in the low-temperature range due to the combustion of the carbidic carbon in Ni
3
GaC
x
.
(63,64)

SEM images of the spent catalysts (
Figure S14
) showed that the surface of Ni/MgO was completely covered with filamentous carbons, whereas NMG-600 retained its original plate-like morphology with no filamentous carbon. These results confirm that the intermetallic Ni
3
Ga structure improves the catalyst stability by inhibiting coke formation. HR-TEM and HAADF-STEM images with the corresponding EDS elemental mapping of the spent catalysts are shown in
Figures
4
c and
S15
. Similar to the XRD, TGA, and SEM results, NMG-600 did not show any observable agglomeration of particles or carbon deposits after the 12 h reaction. However, Ni/MgO showed significant aggregation of Ni particles and carbon nanotube growth on the surface of the catalyst, which are responsible for the catalyst deactivation (
Figure S15
). In the HR-TEM image shown in
Figure
4
c (inset), the
d
-spacing increased slightly from 0.208 to 0.210 nm due to carburization of Ni
3
Ga to Ni
3
GaC
x
. EDS mapping analysis also confirmed that in the Ni
3
Ga particles, carbon was distributed without the formation of graphitic carbon (
Figure
4
c). These results further demonstrate that the Ni
3
GaC
x
phase was formed during the reaction, which confers the high coke resistance of NMG-600. The particle size of the spent catalysts was also investigated by TEM after 12 h of DRM reactions. The NMG-600 catalyst showed a smaller particle size (∼7.3 nm) with a narrower size distribution than NiGa/MgO (∼11.7 nm) prepared by impregnation (
Figures S5a and S11d–f
). The improved dispersion and narrow size distribution of NMG-600 comes from the confinement effect of the LDH-derived structure, which confers high catalytic performance and stability.

div.h3: Dynamic Conversion of the Catalytic Phase under Reaction Conditions
div.div:
Given that the intermetallic carbide Ni
3
GaC
x
was the active catalytic phase, its behavior was studied by
in situ
XRD depending on the gas-phase composition of DRM reaction. As summarized in
Figure
5
, NMG-600 was first reduced to Ni
3
Ga at 600 °C for 5 h under H
2
flow and then carburized under the DRM reaction conditions of CO
2
/CH
4
= 1 at 600 °C for 3 h to form the Ni
3
GaC
x
phase. When, the CO
2
/CH
4
ratio was increased to 2 and 3 while keeping the other conditions constant, the (111) reflection of Ni
3
GaC
x
shifted to a lower
d
-spacing, indicating decarburization of Ni
3
GaC
x
back to Ni
3
Ga (
Figure
5
a, as noted by the blue-colored text). This result indicates that the carbon atoms in Ni
3
GaC
x
readily react with CO
2
to form CO on the catalyst surface (
eq 8
). When the gas ratio returned to CO
2
/CH
4
= 1, the observed XRD pattern was identical to the initial XRD pattern, indicating that the carbon atoms generated from CH
4
decomposition re-filled the interstitial sites of Ni
3
Ga (
eq 9
). To confirm the reaction of Ni
3
GaC
x
with CO
2
during DRM (
eq 8
), only CO
2
was flown over Ni
3
GaC
x
at 400 °C. The outlet gas stream contained only CO (
Figure S16
).
(8)
(9)

div.p:
Figure 5. (a)
In situ
XRD contour maps of the NMG-600 catalyst obtained at different CH
4
to CO
2
ratios at 600 °C (red: CO
2
/CH
4
= 1, blue: CO
2
/CH
4
= 2, 3). (b) Schematic illustration showing the phase transition between the intermetallic Ni
3
Ga and Ni
3
GaC
x
phases confirmed by
in situ
XRD.

div.div:
The
in situ
XRD portrayed in real time the dynamic structural evolution of the Ni–Ga intermetallic compound in the NMG-600 catalyst, which forms essentially the DRM catalytic cycle depicted in
Scheme 2
. During the reaction, the reversible phase transition between Ni
3
Ga and Ni
3
GaC
x
activates both CO
2
and CH
4
with the elemental carbon as a key reaction intermediate. Because this cycle turns over rapidly for the NMG-600 catalyst, the elemental carbon is quickly removed as the CO product by reacting with CO
2
instead of polymerization to form graphitic carbon to avoid the catalyst deactivation by coking. The mechanism is unique in that the interstitial carbon becomes the reactive intermediate, whereas most of the heterogeneous catalysts involve only surface intermediate species. A similar reaction mechanism was previously reported for molybdenum carbide-based catalysts, which also have high stability for DRM.
(65)
Hence, metal catalysts that can readily form interstitial carbides could follow this type of mechanism.

Scheme 2. Schematic Illustration of the DRM Reaction Mechanism on the LDH-Derived Ni
3
Ga Intermetallic Catalyst
a

figure.p:
a
Reversible transformation between Ni
3
Ga and Ni
3
GaC
x
makes a catalytic cycle to produce CO and H
2
during DRM.

div.h3:
Atomistic Analysis of DRM on the Ni
3
Ga Intermetallic Catalyst
div.div:
The LDH-derived NMG catalyst demonstrated excellent stability due to a high coke resistance and the high activity for the DRM reaction compared to the monometallic Ni/MgO catalyst. To understand the enhanced catalytic performance, we analyzed the DRM reaction mechanism using DFT calculations to evaluate several model surfaces that were expected to be formed during the reaction. Before calculating energetics of the reaction, it is important to specify a plausible catalyst structure. The presence of interstitial carbon in the Ni
3
Ga structure and the resulting lattice expansion during the reaction were demonstrated by
in situ
XRD (
Figure
3
b) and EXAFS (
Figure
4
a). Since it is difficult to determine the precise carbon composition (
x
) of Ni
3
GaC
x
experimentally, the lattice expansion was calculated by adding carbon atoms one by one to the interstitial sites in the Ni
24
Ga
8
supercell, and the results were compared with experimental observations to confirm the carbon composition in
Figure
6
a. The
d
-spacing of the (200) plane from XRD (
Figure
3
b) was 0.179 and 0.181 nm for the reduced (navy line) and spent (red line) catalysts, respectively, indicating an experimental lattice expansion of 1.16%. The lattice of the DFT-optimized Ni
3
GaC
x
structure expanded linearly with
x
and crossed the lattice expansion of 1.16% with a composition of Ni
3
GaC
0.25
(
Figure
6
a). It is noteworthy that a previous report also suggested Ni
3
GaC
0.25
as the equilibrium structure when the synthesis temperature was above 500 °C.
(55)

div.p:
Figure 6. (a) DFT-optimized lattice expansion as a function of carbon composition (
x
) in the Ni
3
GaC
x
structure. (b) Free energy of DRM on Ni (111), Ni
3
Ga (111), and Ni
3
GaC
0.25
(111) surfaces under reaction conditions of
T
= 600 °C and
P
= 0.1 MPa.

div.div:
Figure
6
b shows the overall free-energy profiles of DRM occurring on Ni, Ni
3
Ga, and Ni
3
GaC
0.25
surfaces. The (111) surface was adopted as the catalyst for all three models due to its lowest surface energy. The energy profile is grouped into three parts: (1) decomposition of CH
4
(g) into C* and four H* atoms, (2) conversion of CO
2
(g) and C* into two CO*s, and (3) desorption of CO* and H* into CO(g) and H
2
(g). Here, (g) and * denote the gas-phase molecule and chemisorbed surface species, respectively.

In the CH
4
decomposition step, the three catalysts appeared to have similar free-energy profiles except for the slightly stronger adsorption of the CH
x
species on the Ni
3
GaC
0.25
surface. On the other hand, the energy profiles of the CO
2
conversion step showed significant differences between different catalysts. In particular, the Ni
3
Ga and Ni
3
GaC
0.25
catalysts clearly required less energy than Ni for the oxidation of C* to CO*. Based on the Brønsted–Evans–Polanyi principle,
(66)
the low energy requirements of the Ni
3
Ga and Ni
3
GaC
0.25
catalysts can be explained contrastively. In the case of the Ni
3
Ga catalyst, the lowest free-energy level for the C* oxidation is due to the highly stable CO* formation, which makes the transition state closer in energy to the final state. However, the strong CO* binding is detrimental to the following desorption step. In the case of the Ni
3
GaC
0.25
catalyst, the formation of C* is energetically less favorable, which means that the decomposition of CH* requires more energy. However, once C* is formed, its oxidation to CO* and subsequent desorption proceed readily, as shown in the last part of
Figure
6
b. The relative formation energy and atomic configuration of each adsorbate are listed in
Table S3
.

The activation energies of individual reactions calculated without thermodynamic corrections are summarized in
Table
1
. During the CH
4
dehydrogenation process, Ni and Ni
3
GaC
0.25
exhibited similar kinetic barriers with a difference of less than 0.1 eV in each reaction from the first C–H activation to C* formation. Conversely, Ni
3
Ga required more energy for the first C–H bond activation than Ni and Ni
3
GaC
0.25
. This indicates that the high CH
4
conversion activity of the LDH-derived NMG originates from the presence of the interstitial carbon in the Ni
3
Ga lattice.
Table 1. Activation Energies of Elementary Reactions of DRM

The interstitial carbon also inhibits coke formation. By forming CO* on Ni
3
GaC
0.25
, the surface carbon is removed more rapidly than with the other catalysts because the kinetic barrier (1.18 eV) is significantly lower than those of Ni (1.59 eV) and Ni
3
Ga (1.43 eV). These results provide a clear insight into the DRM reaction mechanism over the intermetallic catalyst. The LDH-derived Ni
3
Ga intermetallic catalyst is converted to Ni
3
GaC
0.25
because the carbon atoms generated from CH
4
penetrate into the octahedral interstices of the Ni
3
Ga lattice during DRM at 600 °C. Both the Ni
3
Ga and Ni
3
GaC
0.25
intermetallic catalysts require less energy than Ni to form CO by carbon oxidation. In particular, Ni
3
GaC
0.25
is most effective in rapidly converting the carbon formed on the catalyst into CO and plays a crucial role in suppressing the formation of coke on the catalyst surface, thereby significantly improving the catalyst stability.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
NMG-LDH was used as an efficient precursor to a Ni
3
Ga intermetallic compound uniformly embedded on the MgO support. The obtained Ni
3
Ga/MgO intermetallic catalyst showed higher activity as well as stability in DRM than a monometallic Ni/MgO catalyst or a physical mixture of Ni/MgO and Ga/MgO. In particular, the Ni
3
Ga intermetallic catalyst exhibited excellent stability without suffering deactivation by coking even at the relatively low temperature of 600 °C over a long reaction time of 72 h. Characterizations including XRD, HR-TEM, HAADF-STEM, EDS, XPS, TGA, H
2
-TPR, CO
2
-TPD, and XAS demonstrated that the Ni
3
GaC
x
phase is formed during the reaction, leading to high coke resistance. The real-time monitoring by
in situ
XRD revealed a reversible phase transition between Ni
3
Ga and Ni
3
GaC
x
with the interstitial carbon being involved in a catalytic cycle of DRM to produce CO and H
2
. DFT calculations determined the most plausible Ni
3
GaC
0.25
structure and overall free-energy profiles of DRM to clarify the reaction mechanism. The LDH-derived Ni
3
Ga intermetallic catalyst is converted to the Ni
3
GaC
0.25
phase because the carbon atoms dissociated from CH
4
penetrate into the octahedral interstices of the Ni
3
Ga lattice during the DRM at 600 °C. In particular, the formed Ni
3
GaC
0.25
intermetallic carbide readily reacts with CO
2
to form CO, which plays a crucial role in suppressing the formation of coke on the catalyst surface. This study provides valuable insights for preparing intermetallic catalysts with a high stability against coking that deactivates DRM catalysts.

A review. In recent years, Carbon Capture and Storage (Sequestration) (CCS) has been proposed as a potential method to allow the continued use of fossil-fuelled power stations while preventing emissions of CO2 from reaching the atm. Gas, coal (and biomass)-fired power stations can respond to changes in demand more readily than many other sources of electricity prodn., hence the importance of retaining them as an option in the energy mix. Here, we review the leading CO2 capture technologies, available in the short and long term, and their technol. maturity, before discussing CO2 transport and storage. Current pilot plants and demonstrations are highlighted, as is the importance of optimizing the CCS system as a whole. Other topics briefly discussed include the viability of both the capture of CO2 from the air and CO2 reutilization as climate change mitigation strategies. Finally, we discuss the economic and legal aspects of CCS.

A review. While Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) technologies are being developed with the focus of capturing and storing CO2 in huge quantities, new methods for the chem. exploitation of carbon dioxide (CCU) are being developed in parallel. The intensified chem. or phys. utilization of CO2 is targeted at generating value from a limited part of the CO2 stream and developing better and more efficient chem. processes with reduced CO2 footprint. Here, we compare the status of the three main lines of CCS technologies with respect to efficiency, energy consumption, and tech. feasibility as well as the implications of CCS on the efficiency and structure of the energy supply chain.

A review. Recycling CO2 as a renewable carbon source for the prodn. of high-value fuels and chems. has drawn global attention lately as a promising method to mitigate climate change and lessen dependence on fossil fuels. Among the available CO2-recycling options, catalytic CO2 hydrogenation is the most realistic and attractive choice if the hydrogen is produced using a renewable energy source. Depending on the nature of the catalyst, CO2 hydrogenation has distinct reaction pathways, and various value-added hydrocarbons can be produced. Intense research has recently developed high-performance catalysts, identified clear reaction pathways, and deepened the understanding of the reaction mechanisms. In this review, we present an overview of recent key advances in catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to high-value hydrocarbons and oxygenates that have large market sizes, such as formic acid, methanol, methane, and light olefins, as well as liq. fuels, in terms of the catalyst design, catalytic performance, and reaction mechanism. In addn., the current tech. challenges and perspectives on CO2 conversion processes are discussed with regard to climate change mitigation.

Kim, Kwang Young; Lee, Hojeong; Noh, Woo Yeong; Shin, Jungho; Han, Seung Ju; Kim, Seok Ki; An, Kwangjin; Lee, Jae Sung

Monodisperse nanoparticles (NPs) of CoFe2O4 were synthesized as efficient catalyst precursors for CO2 hydrogenation to produce high value-added C2-C4 olefin products, which are important building blocks for the chem. industry. The resulting Na-promoted CoFe2O4 catalysts supported on carbon nanotubes (Na-CoFe2O4/CNT) exhibited high CO2 conversion (~ 34%) and light olefin selectivity (~ 39%), outperforming other reported Fe-based catalysts under similar reaction conditions. Their performance was superior to that of single-metal NP catalysts (Na-Fe3O4/CNT and Na-Co/CNT) and a phys. mixed (Na-Fe3O4 + Co)/CNT catalyst. The superior performance of the Na-CoFe2O4/CNT catalyst can be attributed to the facile formation of a unique bimetallic alloy carbide (Fe1-xCox)5C2, which results in higher CO2 conversion and better selectivity toward light olefins in comparison with conventional χ-Fe5C2 active sites derived from Fe-only catalysts and significantly improved heavy hydrocarbon (C2+) formation in comparison with the Co2C sites of Co-only catalysts. The single-source precursor CoFe2O4 exclusively forms a single-phase alloy carbide promoted by the Na promoter, whereas the mixed (Na-Fe3O4 + Co) precursor forms an isolated Co phase with the alloy carbide phase, promoting undesirable CH4 formation. An optimal value of x ≤ 0.2 for (Fe1-xCox)5C2 was predicted using the cluster expansion method and d. functional theory, resulting in a stable bimetallic alloy structure.

Dry (CO2) reforming of methane (DRM) is a well-studied reaction that is of both scientific and industrial importance. This reaction produces syngas that can be used to produce a wide range of products, such as higher alkanes and oxygenates by means of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. DRM is inevitably accompanied by deactivation due to carbon deposition. DRM is also a highly endothermic reaction and requires operating temps. of 800-1000 °C to attain high equil. conversion of CH4 and CO2 to H2 and CO and to minimize the thermodn. driving force for carbon deposition. The most widely used catalysts for DRM are based on Ni. However, many of these catalysts undergo severe deactivation due to carbon deposition. Noble metals have also been studied and are typically found to be much more resistant to carbon deposition than Ni catalysts, but are generally uneconomical. Noble metals can also be used to promote the Ni catalysts in order to increase their resistance to deactivation. In order to design catalysts that minimize deactivation, it is necessary to understand the elementary steps involved in the activation and conversion of CH4 and CO2. This review will cover DRM literature for catalysts based on Rh, Ru, Pt, and Pd metals. This includes the effect of these noble metals on the kinetics, mechanism and deactivation of these catalysts.

A a comprehensive review with 62 refs. of the thermodn., catalyst selection and activity, reaction mechanism, and kinetics of carbon dioxide reforming of methane to produce synthesis gas over metal-supported catalysts. Recently, research has centered on the development of catalysts and the feasible applications of this reaction in industry. Group VIII metals supported on oxides are found to be effective for this reason. However, carbon deposition causing catalyst deactivation is the major problem inhibiting the industrial application of the CO2/CH4 reaction. Ni-based catalysts impregnated on certain supports show carbon-free operation and thus attract much attention. To develop an effective catalyst for CO2 reforming of CH4 and accelerate the com. application of the reaction, the following are identified to be the most important areas for future work: (1) selection of metal and support and studying the effect of their interaction on catalyst activity; (2) the effect of different promoter on catalyst activity; (3) the reaction mechanism and kinetics; and (4) pilot reactor performance and scale-up operation.

CO2 dry reforming of methane (DRM) not only utilized the two greenhouse gases, CO2 and CH4, but also produced synthesis gas, which could be used for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Besides, DRM reaction could utilize marsh gas and the gaseous products from pyrolysis of biomass, consequently increasing their value for businesses and reducing environment pollution, thereby providing ways for sustainable development. Nickel based catalyst was widely used in DRM reaction. This paper reviewed the recent progresses of the DRM reaction at low temp. Suitable supports and promoters improved the catalytic performance by adjusting the interaction between nickel and the support. Besides, the temp. of calcination, the order of materials loading on support, the redn. temp., and the nickel particle size also altered the performance of the catalysts. It was suggested that by investigating the interaction of supports, promoters with nickel, as well as their structural adjustment, the development of low temp. DRM catalysts was feasible.

Usman, Muhammad; Wan Daud, W. M. A.; Abbas, Hazzim F.

This review will explore the influences of the active metal, support, promoter, prepn. methods, calcination temp., reducing environment, particle size and reactor choice on catalytic activity and carbon deposition for the dry reforming of methane. Bimetallic (Ni-Pt, Ni-Rh, Ni-Ce, Ni-Mo, Ni-Co) and monometallic (Ni) catalysts are preferred for dry reforming compared to noble metals (Rh, Ru and Pt) due to their low-cost. Investigation of support materials indicated that ceria-zirconia mixts., ZrO2 with alkali metals (Mg2+, Ca2+, Y2+) addn., MgO, SBA-15, ZSM-5, CeO2, BaTiO3 and Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 showed improved catalytic activities and decreased carbon deposition. The modifying effects of cerium (Ce), magnesium (Mg) and yttrium (Y) were significant for dry reforming of methane. MgO, CeO2 and La2O3 promoters for metal catalysts supported on mesoporous materials had the highest catalyst stability among all the other promoters. Prepn. methods played an important role in the synthesis of smaller particle size and higher dispersion of active metals. Calcination temp. and treatment duration imparted significant changes to the morphol. of catalysts as evident by XRD, TPR and XPS. Catalyst redn. in different environments (H2, He, H2/He, O2/He, H2-N2 and CH4/O2) indicated that probably the mixt. of reducing agents will lead to enhanced catalytic activities. Smaller particle size (<15 nm) had a significant influence on the suppression of carbon deposition and catalytic activity. Fluidized bed reactor exhibited the highest activity and stability, lower carbon deposition and higher conversion compared to a fixed-bed reactor. Moreover, membrane reactor, solar reactor, high-pressure reactor and microreactor were also investigated with specific features such as: pure H2 prodn., detailed reaction information with enhanced safety, higher pressure applications and dry reforming reaction with/without catalyst under sunlight. The study of parameters would improve the understanding of various prepn. and reaction conditions leading to various catalytic activities.

Ni incorporated and Ni-Rh incorporated bimetallic MCM-41 like mesoporous catalysts, which were synthesized following a one-pot hydrothermal procedure, showed very high activity in dry reforming of methane. Among the Ni incorporated catalysts, Ni-MCM-41-V, with a Ni/Si ratio of 0.19, showed the best catalytic performance. Rh incorporation into this catalyst by the one-pot procedure improved both activity and time on stream stability of the catalyst. However, Rh incorporation by impregnation caused instabilities due to coke formation, after about 11 h of reaction time. Occurrence of reverse water gas shift reaction caused higher CO selectivity than H2 selectivity, with the Ni incorporated catalysts. Rh incorporation into these catalysts decreased the relative significance of reverse water gas shift reaction, with respect to dry reforming reaction.

Two silica supports either non porous (SiO2) or mesoporous (SBA-15) were impregnated with cobalt (12 wt%) in order to study the confinement effect on catalytic performances in dry reforming of methane. Further increase of activity was obtained by adding small amts. of rhodium (0.2 and 0.5 wt%) to the Co/SBA-15 catalyst. The structural and morphol. properties of the calcined samples were characterized by N2 sorption, X-ray diffraction and high-resoln. transmission electron microscopy (ultra-thin sections). Their reducibility was studied by temp.-programmed redn. After in situ redn. of the materials, their catalytic activity was tested in dry reforming of methane up to 800 °C followed by stability testing at 550 °C for 550 min. Cobalt confinement in the mesopores of SBA-15 is shown to be highly beneficial towards not only activity but also stability, the reduced nanoparticles being then more resistant against sintering under stream. Rh plays a role as an addnl. active phase. It also strongly favors cobalt stabilization in the mesopores by permitting its redn. at a much lower temp., which allows avoiding metal migration to the surface of the silica grains. The nature of coke is also shown to depend on rhodium addn., with less amt. of carbon gamma (graphitic and destructive form) formed on the Rh-contg. sample compared to the Rh-free Co/SBA-15 catalyst.

Ni/CeZrO2 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts promoted by Pt were explored for dry reforming of methane at temps. ranging from 100 °C to 800 °C. Temp. programmed redn. (TPR) and temp. programmed reaction studies showed that Pt increases the reducibility of Ni-based monometallic catalysts. TPR studies suggested an alloy formation between Pt and Ni. The induction period with the Pt is much lower than on the Ni alone esp. on the Al2O3. A mechanism involving more steam reforming due to more water consumption is proposed for the reaction on alumina supported catalysts.

Large-scale carbon fixation requires high-vol. chems. prodn. from carbon dioxide. Dry reforming of methane could provide an economically feasible route if coke- and sintering-resistant catalysts were developed. Here, we report a molybdenum-doped nickel nanocatalyst that is stabilized at the edges of a single-cryst. magnesium oxide (MgO) support and show quant. prodn. of synthesis gas from dry reforming of methane. The catalyst runs more than 850 h of continuous operation under 60 L per unit mass of catalyst per h reactive gas flow with no detectable coking. Synchrotron studies also show no sintering and reveal that during activation, 2.9 nm as synthesized crystallites move to combine into stable 17-nm grains at the edges of MgO crystals above the Tammann temp. Our findings enable an industrially and economically viable path for carbon reclamation, and the "Nanocatalysts On Single Crystal Edges" technique could lead to stable catalyst designs for many challenging reactions.

Ni stabilised on inorganic complex structures: superior catalysts for chemical CO2 recycling via dry reforming of methane
Le Sache, E.; Pastor-Perez, L.; Watson, D.; Sepulveda-Escribano, A.; Reina, T. R.
Applied Catalysis, B: Environmental
(
2018
),
236
(
),
458-465
CODEN:
ACBEE3
; ISSN:
0926-3373
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
CO2 utilization is becoming an appealing topic in catalysis science due to the urgent need to deal with greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions. Herein, the dry reforming of methane (DRM) represents a viable route to convert CO2 and CH4 (two of the major GHG) into syngas, a highly valuable intermediate in chem. synthesis. Nickel-based catalysts are economically viable materials for this reaction, however they show inevitable signs of deactivation. In this work stabilization of Ni in a pyrochlore-perovskite structure is reported as a viable method to prevent fast deactivation. Substitution of Zirconium by Ni at various loadings in the lanthanum zirconate pyrochlore La2Zr2O7 is investigated in terms of reactant conversions under various reaction conditions (temp. and space velocity). XRD anal. of the calcined and reduced catalysts showed the formation of cryst. phases corresponding to the pyrochlore structure La2Zr2-xNixO7-δ and an addnl. La2NiZrO6 perovskite phase at high Ni loadings. Carbon formation is limited using this formulation strategy and, as a consequence, our best catalyst shows excellent activity for DRM at temps. as low as 600 °C and displays great stability over 350 h of continuous operation. Exsoln. of Ni from the oxide structure, leading to small and well dispersed Ni clusters, could explain the enhanced performance.

Carbon dioxide reforming of methane (DRM) reaction has been widely explored since it is a sustainable process to transform carbon dioxide and methane which are the main greenhouse gases to value added synthesis gas. Herein,
[email protected]
[email protected]
core shell hollow spheres (
[email protected]
@SiO2 HS) with high carbon resistance for DRM at 600°C (10.4% wt. loss after 50 h reaction) have been designed. Addnl., it also showed stable and high conversions (82.5% and 78.4% for carbon dioxide and methane resp.) and carbon resistance (5.5% wt. loss) for DRM reaction at 700°C within the testing time of 600 h. By contrast, for
[email protected]
without SiO2 shell, tremendous carbon nanotubes (CNTs) formed for DRM at 600°C, even though it is interesting to find that there is slight nickel sintering. TPO-MS, H2-TPR, XPS and TEM characterizations showed that the interactions between nickel nanoparticles and NiPhy materials were increased due to the coating of SiO2 shell which also confined nickel and inhibited detaching of nickel from the surface of
[email protected]
@SiO2, which eliminates the accumulation of carbon to become CNTs. The synthesis method for core shell HS provides numerous opportunities to design other structured materials such as Ni-M (M = Co, Fe, Mg)@SiO2 HS for the efficient utilization of greenhouse gases through environmentally sustainable processes.

18
In Situ Elucidation of the Active State of Co-CeOx Catalysts in the Dry Reforming of Methane: The Important Role of the Reducible Oxide Support and Interactions with Cobalt
Zhang, Feng; Liu, Zongyuan; Zhang, Shuhao; Akter, Nusnin; Palomino, Robert M.; Vovchok, Dimitriy; Orozco, Ivan; Salazar, David; Rodriguez, Jose A.; Llorca, Jordi; Lee, Jaeha; Kim, DoHeui; Xu, Wenqian; Frenkel, Anatoly I.; Li, Yuanyuan; Kim, Taejin; Senanayake, Sanjaya D.

(
2018
),
8
(
4
),
3550-3560
CODEN:
ACCACS
; ISSN:
2155-5435
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
The activation of methane and its dry reforming with CO2 was systematically studied over a series (2-30 wt %) of Co (∼5 nm in size) loaded CeO2 catalysts, with an effort to elucidate the interplay between Co and CeO2 during the catalytic process using in situ methods. The results of in situ time-resolved X-ray diffraction (TR-XRD) show a strong interaction of methane with the CoOx-CeO2 systems at temps. between 200 and 350 °C. The hydrogen produced by the dissocn. of C-H bonds in methane leads to a full redn. of Co oxide, Co3O4 → CoO → Co, and a partial redn. of ceria with the formation of some Ce3+. Upon the addn. of CO2, a catalytic cycle for dry reforming of methane (DRM) was achieved on the CoOx-CeO2 powder catalysts at temps. below 500 °C. A 10 wt % Co-CeO2 catalyst was found to possess the best catalytic activity among various cobalt loading catalysts, and it exhibits a desirable stability for the DRM with a minimal effect of carbon accumulation. The phase transitions and the nature of active components in the catalyst were investigated under reaction conditions by in situ time-resolved XRD and ambient-pressure XPS (AP-XPS). These studies showed dynamic evolutions in the chem. compn. of the catalysts under reaction conditions. CO2 attenuated the reducing effects of methane. Under optimum CO- and H2-producing conditions, both XRD and AP-XPS indicated that the active phase involved a majority of metallic Co with a small amt. of CoO, both supported on a partially reduced ceria (Ce3+/Ce4+). We identified the importance of dispersing Co, anchoring it onto the ceria surface sites, and then utilizing the redox properties of CeO2 for activating and then oxidatively converting methane while inhibiting coke formation. Furthermore, a synergistic effect between cobalt and ceria and likely the interfacial sites are essential to successfully close the catalytic cycle.

Effect of support oxygen storage capacity on the catalytic performance of Rh nanoparticles for CO2 reforming of methane
Yentekakis, Ioannis V.; Goula, Grammatiki; Hatzisymeon, Maria; Betsi-Argyropoulou, Ioanna; Botzolaki, Georgia; Kousi, Kalliopi; Kondarides, Dimitris I.; Taylor, Martin J.; Parlett, Christopher M. A.; Osatiashtiani, Amin; Kyriakou, Georgios; Holgado, Juan Pedro; Lambert, Richard M.

(

The effects of the metal oxide support on the activity, selectivity, resistance to carbon deposition and high temp. oxidative aging on the Rh-catalyzed dry reforming of methane (DRM) were investigated. Three Rh catalysts supported on oxides characterized by very different oxygen storage capacities and labilities (γ-Al2O3, alumina-ceria-zirconia (ACZ) and ceria-zirconia (CZ)) were studied in the temp. interval 400-750 °C under both integral and differential reaction conditions. ACZ and CZ promoted CO2 conversion, yielding CO-enriched synthesis gas. Detailed characterization of these materials, including state of the art XPS measurements obtained via sample transfer between reaction cell and spectrometer chamber, provided clear insight into the factors that det. catalytic performance. The principal Rh species detected by post reaction XPS was Rh0, its relative content decreasing in the order Rh/CZ(100%)>Rh/ACZ(72%)>Rh/γ-Al2O3(55%). The catalytic activity followed the same order, demonstrating unambiguously that Rh0 is indeed the key active site. Moreover, the presence of CZ in the support served to maintain Rh in the metallic state and minimize carbon deposition under reaction conditions. Carbon deposition, low in all cases, increased in the order Rh/CZ < Rh/ACZ < Rh/γ-Al2O3 consistent with a bi-functional reaction mechanism whereby backspillover of labile lattice O2- contributes to carbon oxidn., stabilization of Rh0 and modification of its surface chem.; the resulting O vacancies in the support providing centers for dissociative adsorption of CO2. The lower apparent activation energy obsd. with CZ-contg. samples suggests that CZ is a promising support component for use in low temp. DRM.

Atomic layer deposition (ALD) was used to deposit Ni and Pt on alumina supports to form monometallic and bimetallic catalysts with initial particle sizes of 1-2.4 nm. The ALD catalysts were more active (per mass of metal) than catalysts prepd. by incipient wetness (IW) for dry reforming of methane (DRM), and they did not form carbon whiskers during reaction due to their sufficiently small size. Catalysts modified by Pt ALD had higher rates of reaction per mass of metal and inhibited coking, whereas NiPt catalysts synthesized by IW still formed carbon whiskers. Temp.-programmed redn. of Ni catalysts modified by Pt ALD indicated the presence of bimetallic interaction. D. functional theory calcns. suggested that under reaction conditions, the NiPt surfaces form Ni-terminated surfaces that are assocd. with higher DRM rates (due to their C and O adsorption energies, as well as the CO formation and CH4 dissocn. energies).

Ru/NaY and Ru/USY catalysts were prepd. by ion exchange from an aq. soln. of [Ru(NH3)6]Cl3. The effect of titanium on the structure of Ru/zeolite introduced by ion exchange or impregnation method from aq. soln. of (NH4)2TiO(C2O4)2·H2O was investigated. The samples were characterized by different techniques, using X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), temp.-programmed desorption of hydrogen (TPD-H2), Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FTIR) of CO adsorption and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Introduction of titanium into Ru/NaY zeolite by ion exchange caused a significant structural collapse of the zeolite framework. Contrary to that, TEM data showed that Ti incorporated into Ru/USY by ion exchange was well distributed within the zeolite cavities. The crystallinity of the USY zeolite decreased significantly after introduction of Ti by impregnation method and a sep. phase of titania was formed. The effect of Ti content on the catalytic behavior of zeolite-supported Ru catalysts in the reaction of CO2 reforming of CH4 was elucidated. The higher specific activity of Ti-contg. catalysts related to CO formation was caused by the both factors, the acceleration of CHxO decompn. (precursor for CO formation) on metal-support interface and participation of the reverse of water gas shift reaction.

Modifying the support of the alumina (Al2O3) supported Ni and Ni-Co catalysts with limited amts. of CaO and MgO had an effect on the catalytic activity during the reforming of CH4 with CO2 at 873 K. The presence of CaO had a favorable effect on the catalytic activity of the supported catalysts. In contrast, the presence of MgO had an adverse effect due to the strong interaction of MgO with the Ni and Co phases under the present synthesis conditions. Characterization of the supported Ni and Ni-Co catalysts revealed that modifying the support with CaO or MgO had an effect on the reducibility, amt. and type of H2 and CO2 chemisorbed and the nature of the metal crystallite. The characterization studies also revealed that the limited interaction of CaO with Ni phase in supported Ni and Ni-Co catalysts gave rise to addnl. sites that were able to chemisorb H2 and CO2 at higher temps. without having a significant effect on the reducibility of the catalysts. The presence of these addnl. sites may be the reason for the improved activity of the modified-Al2O3 supported Ni and Ni-Co catalysts contg. CaO.

A series of bimetallic Fe-Ni/MgAl2O4 catalysts with Fe/Ni ratios between 0 and 1.5 were examd. for methane dry reforming at 923-1073 K, atm. pressure, and a CH4/CO2 ratio of 1. The evolution of the catalyst structure during H2 temp.-programmed redn. (TPR), CO2 temp.-programmed oxidn. (TPO), and dry reforming is examd. using time-resolved in situ x-ray diffraction (x-ray diffraction). During H2-TPR up to 973 K, Fe2O3 and NiO are reduced to Fe and Ni. Higher temps. lead to Fe-Ni alloy formation. The alloy remains stable up to 900 K under CO2-TPO and is decompd. to Ni and Fe3O4 at higher temps. The Fe-Ni alloy is the active phase while Fe partially segregates from the alloy forming FeOx during dry reforming. This is beneficial as it reduces the surface carbon accumulation through interaction with FeOx lattice oxygen, producing CO. Alternate CH4 and CO2 pulse expts. over Ni, Fe, and Ni-Fe samples showed that dry reforming over Fe-Ni catalysts can follow a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. A molar Fe/Ni ratio of 0.7 provides the most active and least deactivated catalyst. All studied catalysts can be regenerated by CO2 carbon removal.

Dry reforming of methane on Ni-Fe-MgO catalysts: Influence of Fe on carbon-resistant property and kinetics
Zhang, Tingting; Liu, Zhongxian; Zhu, Yi-An; Liu, Zhicheng; Sui, Zhijun; Zhu, Kake; Zhou, Xinggui
Applied Catalysis, B: Environmental
(
2020
),

(
),

CODEN:
ACBEE3

0926-3373
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
Dry reforming of methane (DRM) converts two major greenhouse gases into syngas, a versatile chem. feedstock, requiring the identification of a robust catalyst. In this contribution, we explored the promoting effect of Fe in MgO supported Ni-Fe alloy catalysts in DRM. Towards this end, a series of catalysts with varied Fe/(Ni+Fe) ratios (0 to 0.17) and homogeneous metal distribution were prepd. from a single FexNiyMg1-x-y(OH)2 (x = 0.00-0.07, y = 0.00-0.07) precursor derived from solvothermal synthesis. Catalytic evaluations at 760°C and 800°C showed that Fe passivated the activity of Ni surface while promoting the coke-tolerant property. Structural evolution and coke deposition of catalysts were extensively characterized by using XRD, SEM, TEM, HAADF-HRTEM, H2-TPR, CO2 (O2)-TGA and CO2-TPO techniques, manifesting that alloying of Fe with Ni had enhanced catalyst stability. Lowered amt. of coke was found on spent Ni-Fe alloy catalysts with respect to pristine Ni catalyst, and Fe also changed the type of surface carbon from a refractory type to a soft one that can be readily gasified by CO2. Fe also increased the surface oxyphilicity of alloy particle surface via balancing the otherwise carbon affinity of Ni surface. Optimized catalytic performance was attained by FexNi0.07-xMg0.93O-R (x = 0.003-0.006) catalyst. Kinetic studies and coke gasification kinetic disclosed that Fe slowed down coke deposition rate and concomitantly accelerated surface coke gasification rate, without changing the essential reaction mechanism or kinetic features of pristine Ni catalyst. The promoting effect of Fe was found to be highly dependent on CO2 contents in the contacting atm., as well as Fe/Ni ratios in the alloy. The stability of Ni-Fe alloy catalyst in DRM can be ascribed to combined effects from both ensemble size redn. and surface oxyphilicity change. The role Fe plays in enhancing DRM coke-resistant property is potentially useful for alike reforming catalyst and process design.

Reduced perovskite LaNiO3 catalysts modified with Co and Mn for low coke formation in dry reforming of methane
Kim, Won Yong; Jang, Jum Suk; Ra, Eun Cheol; Kim, Kwang Young; Kim, Eun Hyup; Lee, Jae Sung

In dry reforming of methane (DRM), coke deposition on the Ni-based catalyst is the main cause of instability of the process. Perovskite LaNiO3 is a well-known highly active catalyst precursor for DRM, but the La-Ni catalyst derived from it is susceptible to severe coke deposition and thus difficult for practical applications. To improve its stability and activity, Co and Mn are introduced to develop a tri-metallic LaNi0.34Co0.33Mn0.33O3 catalyst precursor. The role of Mn is to improve the stability of the catalyst, whereas Co is an addnl. active component to increase the reaction rates. A strong metal and support interaction mediated by MnO is noted in the tri-metallic catalyst, which contributes to a synergistic effect of the tri-metals to sustain the high activity and stability under the harsh conditions of DRM.

Dry reforming of methane (DRM) is an effective route to convert methane and carbon dioxide to syngas. Herein, we report an efficient nickel-cobalt bimetallic catalyst with an activity of 4.97 molCH4 molNi-1 s-1 at 800 °C. It is active at low temp. as well, and near-thermodn. equil. conversion was achieved as low as 350 °C, with a high yield of H2 implying inhibition of side reactions: i.e., a reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction. The formation of Ni-Co alloy during the reaction was obsd., and its lattice contraction was revealed by HAADF-STEM and EXAFS expts. The lattice-strained Ni-Co alloy has good CO2 dissocn. ability, which is responsible for its superior catalytic performance. Its weak chemisorption with H2 results in inhibition of RWGS side reactions. This work is helpful in the design and development of other metal alloy materials with novel structures and/or electronic configurations for catalytic applications.

In this paper, a novel sandwiched core-shell structured
[email protected]
catalyst, with nickel nanoparticles encapsulated between silica and ceria, was developed and applied for dry reforming of biogas (CH4 / CO2 = 3/2) under low temp. conditions to test its coke inhibition properties. Ni-phyllosilicate was used as the Ni precursor in order to produce highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles on SiO2. Cerium oxide was chosen as the shell due to its high redox potential and oxygen storage capacity, that can reduce coke formation under severe dry reforming conditions. The core shell
[email protected]
catalyst showed excellent coke inhibition property under low temp. (600 °C) reforming of biogas, with no coke detected after a 72 h catalytic run. Under the same conditions, Ni-SiO2 catalyst deactivated within 22 h due to heavy coke formation and reactor blockage, while Ni-CeO2 catalyst showed very low activity. The higher activity of the core-shell catalyst is attributed to its higher Ni dispersion and reducibility. TEM and XRD results show that the core-shell catalyst shows higher resistance to Ni particle sintering and agglomeration during the reaction than the Ni-SiO2 and Ni-CeO2 catalysts. In-situ DRIFTS on the
[email protected]
catalyst indicate a change in the reaction mechanism from a mono-functional pathway on the Ni-SiO2 catalysts to a bi-functional route on the
[email protected]
catalyst with active participation of oxygen species from CeO2 in carbon gasification. The confinement effect of the sandwich structure and the bifunctional mechanism of dry reforming are the primary reasons for the excellent coke resistance of the
[email protected]
catalyst.

Ordered mesoporous Ni-Ce-Al composite oxides with various Ce contents were synthesized via a 1-pot route: evapn.-induced self-assembly (EISA) strategy and tested in methane dry reforming for H and synthesis gas prodn. Using this method, the hydrophobic Ni precursor was directly incorporated into the hydrophobic cores of surfactant micelles, and thus, the highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles were stabilized inside the mesopore channels of an alumina matrix. For comparison, Ni-based catalysts were also prepd. by a traditional impregnation method. The characterization results confirmed that the ordered mesostructures were well maintained in all of the Ce-incorporated Ni-Al materials (Ce/(Ce + Al) molar ratio ≤ 3%). The catalyst with a Ce/(Ce + Al) ratio of 1% exhibited the highest catalytic activity (with CO2 and CH4 initial conversions being 70% and 68% at 700°, resp.) and remained stable in a methane dry reforming reaction. This improved activity can be attributed to the large surface area and high dispersion and reducibility of Ni nanoparticles, which were stable because of the stable alumina framework and high O mobility in these Ce-contg. samples. Resistance to C deposition was found over the Ni-Ce-Al catalyst, whereas amts. of graphitic C species were found over the Ni-impregnated catalysts, which was responsible for deactivation.

In this study, Ni-MCM-41 based catalysts (with a Ni/Si molar ratio of 0.2), contg. different amts. of Ru (0.5-3.0 wt.%) and Mg (1 and 5 wt.%) were prepd. by using sequential impregnation of Ru and Mg into Ni-MCM-41. Ru incorporation (1.0% Ru) was shown to improve H2 yields. Mg impregnation into
[email protected]
improved catalytic performance by increasing CH4 conversion and decreasing the contribution of reverse water gas shift reaction, esp. at initial times (first 60 min).
